div.head: “The Constellations: Northern, Some of the Zodiac, and Some of the Southern”
Title
div.p: MS III, Ruskin wrote the title as “THE CONSTELLATIONS / NORTHERN, SOME OF THE ZODIAC AND / SOME OF THE SOUTHERN.” In MS IA, he wrote the title nearly identically, merely breaking the lines differently, as “THE CONSTELLATIONS NORTHERN / SOME OF THE ZODIAC / AND SOME OF THE SOUTHERN.” In RF T70, the extension “NOTHERN . . . SOUTHERN is placed awkwardly, as if possibly inserted as an afterthought.
See System of Title Citation for Works.

div.head: MSS IA and III, RF T70
div.p: MS IA; MS III; RF T70.
In MS III, a Red Book devoted initially to “Harry and Lucy,” Vol. 2, “The Constellations” is the first poem in the MS III Second Poetry Anthology.
Facsimiles by permission of John Ruskin Collection, General Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Transcriptions of texts and commentary © David C. Hanson.

div.head: January (or January 1827?)
div.p: Undated fair copy in MS III, where title written “THE CONSTELLATIONS / NORTHERN, SOME OF THE ZODIAC AND / SOME OF THE SOUTHERN.”. Its placement after the second volume of “Harry and Lucy” and before “The Sun” suggests New Yearʼs 1828. Indeed, in the prose section of MS III preceding the poem, Harry gives Lucy a drawing of Charlesʼs Wain “as an introduction to astronomy”. Thus, Ruskinʼs editors are strictly correct in listing the poem under 1827—that is, composition in late 1827 for a New Yearʼs 1828 presentation.

The editors seem to intend earlier 1827, associating the poem with the rough draft of “The Monastery” in MS IA, which they misdate as 1827. If they based their dating on harder evidence contained in the rough draft of “Constellations” in MS IA (see Works, 2:535), their reasoning cannot be confirmed or denied, since a piece of that rough draft manuscript is now very likely missing. The evidence in MS III does hold open a possibility for an earlier date. As noted in nos. 1 and 4, Ruskin seems habitually to have included his previous yearʼs presentation poems along with the most recent New Yearʼs gift in his “Harry and Lucy” books (e.g., in MS III, Ruskin includes another older New Yearʼs poem, no. 4, in this group). Thus, “The Constellations” could have existed as a New Yearʼs gift for 1827, although no positive evidence supports the possibility.

If the poem is based on Ruskinʼs actual observation of the sky, the alignment of heavenly bodies described at the beginning of the poem would not have been possible in 1827, not even as late as December for a New Yearʼs composition. In that case, the composition would have to be moved forward to April‐May 1828, more in keeping with the occasion of John Jamesʼs birthday. See Discussion.

div.head: Composition and Publication
div.p: Quoted in Ruskin, Works, 2:260 n. 1. Previously unpublished in entirety.

A separate presentation copy of the poem is represented at the Ruskin Library by a photograph of a manuscript, taken for the Library Edition but unused (RF T70; for its physical description, see part 2, MS IA, “Contents,” b). The location of the original manuscript is unknown, as are the occasion and date of its presentation, and its physical characteristics, other than its consisting of a single folded sheet. Entitled “THE CONSTELLATIONS NORTHERN / SOME OF THE ZODIAC / AND SOME OF THE SOUTHERN”, the photograph shows a fair‐copy version predating the MS III fair copy. It runs the full length of the MS III version, but several lines are crossed out and revisions scrawled in the margins—revisions that all appear in the MS III version, excepting a word or two that were altered again for that final version. The revisions are written in an awkward longhand, unlike the tiny print lettering of the fair copy. Presumably, the RF T70 revisions were made shortly before the late 1827—early 1828 fair copy in MS III (thus, incidentally, representing one of the earliest datable examples of Ruskinʼs longhand script). In fact, the RF T70 fair copy itself, and not just its revisions, may have only shortly predated the MS III version. At line 53 of RF T70, the fair‐copy hand suddenly becomes larger and more careless, suggesting that, at this point, Ruskin decided to sacrifice this fair copy to revision (see also textual note for line 54). On the last page of the folded sheet (i.e., p. 4) in the photograph, revised lines of “The Constellations” appear to be written over top of a lighter script of lines that I am unable to connect definitely with any extant fair‐copy juvenilia: “[to(?)] heaven but / not [to(?)] hell [for when (?)] / they went to / place [I(?)] say [that then (?)] / they took quite / a different way / and . . .” (the writing continues for four more, illegible lines). The scrawled draft suggests notes for a sermon, although it might represent attempted revision of “The Constellations” since some lines were given a more pious cast in the final version (see, e.g., the textual notes for the lines “The scales in which twas vainly said / The crime and virtues of men were weighed,” and for the closing meditation on the superiority of virtue to knowledge). No surviving fair‐copy lines, however, even remotely match the faint draft.

div.head: Sources
div.p: Definitive evidence of one source of Ruskinʼs reading about the constellations is revealed in his “Harry and Lucy . . . Vol 2”, where Harry offers to “give . . . [Lucy] a drawing of charlesʼs wain as an introduction to astronomy”. The drawing, which Ruskin illustrates with his own drawing in the text, reproduces a diagram in volume 2, “Of Astronomy”, of Jeremiah Joyceʼs Scientific Dialogues. In Joyceʼs dialogue, the Tutor shows this diagram to his pupils, Charles and James, just as Ruskinʼs Harry presents the drawing to Lucy, as a first step in learning “‘how to distinguish the stars, and . . . call them by their proper names’”. He points out Charlesʼ Wain in the night sky, and describes the formation using the diagram—four stars forming a waggon, and three stars making the horses, all of them also forming part of a larger constellation, the Great Bear or Ursa Major. This constellation, he explains, can serve as a compass for finding oneʼs bearings at night, without the sunʼs position to define east and west. As a northern, circumpolar constellation, Charlesʼ Wain is always visible on a clear night; and as the diagram shows, it points to the North Star (i.e., Polaris) if one traces a line upward through the two stars forming the rear of the waggon. From this first point of reference, the Tutor proceeds to instruct Charles and James in the names and locations of other stars, constellations, and planets (Joyce, Scientific Dialogues, vol. 2, “Of Astronomy”, coversation 2, “Of the Fixed Stars”, 2:12–18, 250 opp. [pl. 1, fig. 1]).

In Ruskinʼs reading about the constellations, this episode in Joyceʼs dialogues formed a node of interlocking texts, for in Maria Edgeworthʼs Frank: A Sequel the Engineer marks passages in the Scientific Dialogues where can find information about astronomy. Frank, in turn, recalls an episode in Thomas Dayʼs History of Sandford and Merton, in which “Harry Sandford found his way out of the moor by the help of the pole star” (Edgeworth, Frank: A Sequel, 2:141, 140). In Sandford and Merton, the tutor, Mr. Barlow, cites Harryʼs story of self‐preservation as an instance of practical uses to be derived from scientific understanding, an emphasis likewise imparted but with more detailed and sophisticated scientific information by the Tutor in Scientific Dialogues.

In Sandford and Merton, Tommy ensures they can find Charlesʼ Wain again by diagramming the stars on paper, and he carries on to conceive of a celestial globe in order to map all the constellations. Mr. Barlow obliges with a paper‐covered ball on which the boys can record their own observations of the constellations. While the emphasis is on practical and scientific knowledge, Mr. Barlow also encourages appreciation of natural beauty:

Mr. Barlow. Were there no other use, I should think there would be a very great pleasure in observing such a number of glorious, glittering bodies as are now above us. We sometimes run to see a procession of coaches, or a few people in fine clothes strutting about; we admire a large room that is painted, and ornamented, and gilded: but what is there in all these things to be compared with the sight of these luminous bodies that adorn every part of the sky?
(Day, The History of Sandford and Merton, 165, and see 162–69, 187–88)

The poem “The Constellations” is Ruskinʼs answer to to putting the constellations on paper. In context of Ruskinʼs own “Harry and Lucy . . . Vol 2”, the poem, along with Harryʼs drawing, effectively forms Lucyʼs “introduction to astronomy”; and in the context of Ruskinʼs reading about astronomy, the poemʼs seemingly mechanical exercise of listing the star clusters carries out the method, recommended by Mr. Barlow, of “remembering these stars [forming Charlesʼs Wain]” so that “you may very easily observe those which are next to them, and learn their names too, till you are acquainted with the whole face of the heavens” (Day, History of Sandford and Merton, 163). Just so, in Joyceʼs Scientific Dialogues, the Tutor instructs Charles and James in the names and positions of the constellations.

In his poem, Ruskin adopts the tactic of Dayʼs and Joyceʼs tutors by starting from a prominent point of reference—not, in Ruskinʼs case, a constellation, but a planet, Venus, the so‐called Morning Star and Evening Star, a wandering rather than a fixed star. He carries on to list the formations more or less in sequence, as do Dayʼs Tommy and Harry in drawing constellations on their globe. As a more sophisticated progression, Joyceʼs Tutor leads his pupils from the diagram of Charlesʼs Wain to a celestial globe, which he uses to orient the constellations to the ecliptic and equator; and then he directs the boys to an ephemeris, a catalogue of star positions (Joyce, Scientific Dialogues, vol. 2, “Of Astronomy”, conversations 2–4, 2:12–47). Modern ephemerides were based on exacting observations and mathematical computations, which were the pride of scientifically advanced nations that produced these star catalogues; however, their forbidding tables made the ephemerides a “primary culprit” in driving away public interest in astronomy, displacing the appeal to popular imagination that the stars had presented in the annual almanacs with a professionalization of the science that seemed inaccessible to omateur “sky‐loving men”, in Ruskinʼs phrase (Donnelly, “On the Boredom of Science”, 493–97).

Neither Joyceʼs nor Dayʼs books, however, lists all the constellations named in Ruskinʼs poem. For many of the names and attributes, he used a source that remains to be identified. In the editorial glosses to the poem, some connections are made with books known to have been owned by the family; for the present, the mythology associated with the constellations is glossed using an American text, Astronomical Recreations () by Green.

div.head: Real‐life Observations
div.p: Ruskin possibly derived some of his descriptions of constellations from actual observation of Venus, just as Joyce initially situates his fictional characters observing the evening sky at the end of a lingering walk. A planet is not an obvious starting point for charting the constellations, but the Evening Star and Orion present easy‐to‐find referents for ordinary observers.

According to a digital‐age ephemeris, Venus would have been visible from London as an evening star, setting in the west and appearing close to Orionʼs belt, in March‐May 1828. Mars would not have been visible high in the sky precisely at that time, but would have risen from the east somewhat later, after Venus had set. (An observer might also have confused MarsMars with the bright star, Sirius or “Dog Star”, in the constellation Canis Major directly below Orion.) This particular configuration of planets and constellations would not have appeared at any other time in 1828, and would not have been visible at all in 1827. During those three months in 1828—the time when Ruskin would have been composing poetry for his fatherʼs birthday—the northern constellations could of course also be viewed circling overhead. If the sequence of constellations listed in the poem reflects an actual evening observation, an observer could have looked up from Orion setting in the west, to Ursa Major (the Great Bear) overhead; following the “pointers” in Charlesʼs Wain, the observer would have found the tail of Draco (the Dragon) winding to the northeast; and then turning eastward, he would have encountered Corona Borealis (the Northern Crown) and Coma Berenices (Bereniceʼs Hair).

Hereafter, the sequence in the poem would have shifted the observerʼs gaze erratically around the dome of the sky. For Cygnus (the Swan), he would have turned back to the northeast, looking beyond Draco toward the horizon; and then to find Cor Caroli (Charlesʼs Heart), which is a star in Canes Venatici (Hunting Dogs), he would have turned in the opposite direction, back to the region of Corona Borealis and Coma Berenices (Sky & Telescope, Interactive Star Chart and Celestial Almanac, accessed 20 March 2022).

Beyond this point, the logic of Ruskinʼs repeated “next comes”, if the list represents any plan at all, maps a generally counter‐clockwise rotation, although the sequentially named constellations are not adjacent. The now obsolete constellation Herschellʼs Telescope, which was located within Auriga (the Charioteer), was adjacent neither to the previously named Cor Caroli (Charlesʼs Heart), nor to the subsequently named Equuleus (Little Horse), which lies between Pegasus and Delphinus. Continuing counter‐clockwise brings the viewer to Vulpecula; however, to get from Vulpecula to Lepus—from goose to hare—requires a full semicircle turn, either counter‐clockwise or clockwise (and a dip below the celestial equator, as well), and when Ruskin next shoots up to the pole star in Ursa Minor, all rationale for the arrangement seems lost. Perhaps Ruskin merely wanted to rhyme hare and bear, although, as suggested in the contextual glosses, he may have also have avoided violence by separating the Goose from the Fox in the combined constellation Vulpecula et Anser. have darted in different directions to find ; and so on Of course, if based on any actual observation at all, Ruskinʼs poem may reflect a mix of experience and information gleaned from a book or globe.

A distinct difference between Ruskinʼs poem and Joyceʼs dialogue is that Ruskin is interested in the poetic images evoked by the mythic names, whereas Joyceʼs Tutor and his scholars, while ready to quote illustrative poetry, are dismissive of what they regard as largely humbug: “James. ‘Why are the signs of the Zodiac called by the several names of Aries, Taurus, Leo, &c. I see no likeness in the heavens to Rams, or Bulls, or Lions, which are the English words for those Latin ones’. Tutor. ‘Nor do I’” (conversation 4, “Of the Ephemeris”, Scientific Dialogues, 2:36–37). In fact, a lesson that Joyceʼs Tutor dwells on is the arbitrariness underlying the naming systems of astronomy. The imagined patterns in the sky, whereby the Greek ordered and named the constellations, were arbitrary constructions, the Tutor emphasizes: “‘The ancients, that they might the better distinguish and describe the stars, with regard to their situation in the heavens, divided them into constellations, that is, systems of stars, each system consisting of such stars as were near to each other, giving them the names of such men or things, as they fancied the space which they occupied in the heavens represented’”. Charles takes the point: it is “perfectly arbitrary, that one collection is called the great bear, another the dragon; a third Hercules, and so on” (conversation 2, “Of the Fixed Stars”, in Joyce, Scientific Dialogues, 2:13–14). The arbitrariness of naming extends beyond the ancient constellations to modern systems: “‘If you look on the [celestial] globe’”, the Tutor continues, “‘you will observe, that . . . [lesser stars] are distinguished by the different letters of the Greek alphabet’”, which are also assigned arbitrarily (conversation 3, “Of the Fixed Stars, and Ecliptic”, Scientific Dialogues, 2:23).
